AI era is making it a LOT worse. 
claude code being run on machines with private keys, secrets. 
Agentic mode with super permissions so one can wake next morning to see work done. You Tube is filled with, â€œI gave it permissions on the machine. Nothing bad has happened in the past 3 monthsâ€. 
Docker runs, restricted permissions for terminal AI, keeping envs, keys guarded are seemingly all high friction.

And yet, some lessons are never learnt. Years ago I remember the CoPay hack where the node modules scare shook the dev world. The no.1 lesson there was: No â€œ^â€. Keeps happening. Just like wallets keep getting drained. 
Security is a hard habit to acquire. It is â€œinconvenientâ€.

There has been a huge uptick in DPRK activity recently targeting crypto executicves. They have deepfakes of a number of known and unknown people now as part of their phising scam, as well as a big roladex of compromised tg accounts

i think any crypto related project should 
- never use `^` 
- audit __any__ update to a package
- and put their lock files in .gitignore

if you want more sauce - @OxMarco decompiled the DPRK zoom hack which is a strong contender in the making for this

https://github.com/OxMarco/SC-based-CNC-malware

It has clear ability to target npm packages
and then somehow trying to lock it down again with a package-lock file
but in general there are many libs with malware, i think the root cause of this is the `^` auto update versions
well many did not do their security audits and have a dependency on that one ?
It's several packages, not just one
no context no specific lib no nothing, just sensation and engagement farming

Hypotheticals getting too far.
Alex this makes no sense whatsoever.

If bitcoin vol drops to lower than USD vol or even close to it (eg. lower than gold) we have a world base/reserve currency that is outside the control of any government interference. At which point BTC becomes the base ccy that all others are quotes against. It will have more liquidity than USD as all fx will be routed via BTC and all fixed income will be quoted against a BTC discount curve.

That means we will have a non-RWA at the base layer of DeFi which means no tbills backing DeFi, no credit risk, no duration risk. Iâ€™m making a strong assumption that BTC bridges will be significantly hardened by then.

Edit: on reflection I think actually that BTC might never fully be used in this role as: BTC has no risk free rate (eth staking); it will always have bridge risk unlike ETH. Maybe it will always be doomed to be crypto gold and ETH will become the new USD ğŸ˜³

well, there's no obligation to use highly volatile assets right
80% moves wipe leverage, you canâ€™t scale to billions when debt has to reset every couple years.

sorry to barge into your discussion with, possible, limited context 
but - how come BTC volatility affects defi progress?

I donâ€™t think we can have true â€œdecentralised financeâ€ until BTC volatility (vs basket of g10) gets lower than 6% ann. and becomes the base FX pair. DeFi has to move away from fiat to actually stand a chance still decentralisation

IMO defi is too simplistic in general to be left alone without governance (curator) in 99.9% of protocols outside basic AMMs

There is a future where decentralised ML (not an LLM!) may govern but weâ€™re a very long way off

Even then the majority of assets are bridged or derived from RWAs

Cheaper blockspace should in theory let you do lots of cooler stuff that does meet the de in defi angle (eg onchain liquidations, routing, alt clients etc)

And we've had abundant blockspace these days

Moreso up to devs to explore design space and ofc probe if user demand is there

(Un)fortunately this is like a statement about user preference / momentum / what is in vogue and not the diversity / technical improvements 

I'd argue we have many new patterns today (eg isolated lending, various dex designs) that can be and often are maximally decentralized

See eg anything ross has been putting out

https://x.com/z0r0zzz/status/1963155532375826927?t=q-F2sRh9p3MLg5eBERXmlw&s=09

- Equity is decentralised
- Partnerships are DAOs.

The sooner we accept that the better imo.

The things weâ€™re bringing to equity with DeFi are pretty good though â€¦
- global distribution
- no listing fees
- traceability
- instant settlement
- self custody

Itâ€™s these edge cases where itâ€™s nice to have some kind of irl recourse â€¦

dapps are sort of in a weird place in 2025.

One one hand they want to be truly defi but on the other hand theyâ€™re under pressure to implement all sorts of irl frameworks:

- irl credit / op risk (tether, ethena etc)
- irl hack / exploit mgmt (insurance, governance killswitches etc)
- irl compliance (chain analysis black lists as seen above)

The D in defi is almost gone from 99% of protocols and at present we have â€œsmart contract - Fiâ€ that is increasingly governed by equity-like modelsâ€¦ the next step will be bestowing clear rights unto token holders under some regulatory body / legal framework and the circle jerk is complete and we have equity 2.0
